Gant, 556 U.S. ___ 07542, 07542 (2009) hinged on a narrow sub-issue of searches "incident to an arrest"-a SCOTUS doctrine holding that upon arresting someone police may conduct a warrantless search of the person and all areas within his reach. The purpose of the warrantless search incident to arrest is to both make sure the arrestee is not dangerously armed and to prevent the destruction of contraband they might have on their person at the time of arrest. The valid arrest itself justifies this search without a search warrant and without any requirement that the police believe the arrestee is either armed or has contraband on him. 
 
 Gant held that police cannot conduct a warrantless search of the passenger compartment of a vehicle incident to the arrest of an occupant where the arrestee is already held in custody in another vehicle and, at the time of the search, cannot reach to gain access to either weapons or contraband in the suspect vehicle. Gant reverses a trend of expanded vehicle searches incident to arrest and reverts back to the requirement that police have either reasonable suspicion that evidence of the crime the person is being arrested for exists in the vehicle, or probable cause to believe other crime evidence is in the vehicle before they can search it without a warrant.
